Instead, it appears to be floating at some distance away from the top left corner of the image without any visible means for it to move closer to anything else. However, given enough time, even if it doesn't have an immediate destination, gravity alone could cause it to slowly drift downward over time unless acted upon by another force.

In conclusion, under normal conditions where neither object experiences significant interference during freefall, they should each end up inside their designated areas according to our understanding of physics principles governing gravitational motion.
